subj-group.subject: Symposium on Welfare Reform under the Labour Government: Part II

title-group.article-title: Social Security Design in the UK: What is Optimal?

abstract.p: This paper uses a simple model of how households at different points on the income distribution make decisions about saving and labour supply to illustrate some of the problems government faces in designing social security systems. We show simulation results, which highlight the costs and benefits of alternative pension and income support regimes, and analyse what is happening in the UK in the light of the results.

p.mixed-citation: in the late 1990s, the UK Labour Party politician Frank Field resigned from his role as the architect of the government's pension reform strategy largely because he saw the system being steered by his government towards greater use of means testing.
In the present government, the most ardent defender of this principle is Frank Field, who was Minister for Welfare Reform until 1998.

In April 2002, the 'top-up' element of S2P was introduced. The transition to flat-rate benefits was originally set to be in 2006-07, but this date was dropped in the 2002 Green Paper on pensions (Department for Work and Pensions, 2002) pending further consultation.
Only those earning more than the National Insurance lower earnings limit will be considered as making a contribution to their S2P.

We assume taxes are paid on after-saving income. This does not reflect the actual tax system in the UK. There are tax breaks on saving in the UK and much saving is made out of pre-tax income. But it is a simplification to assume all saving is tax-advantaged. In Section VII, where we use a more realistic and complicated model, we drop this assumption.
Because there is little linkage between contributions made and pensions subsequently received, we use the terms 'contribution rate' for the social security system and 'tax rate' interchangeably.
This section follows Miles and Sefton (2002) closely

The first period then corresponds to the first half of the working life (running typically from early 20s to early 40s), the second period is the later half of the working life (running from early 40s to early 60s) and the third period is retirement.
We could just as well set up the income support system so that benefits are not taxed and scale down the benefit payments by the factor 1 -ty-ts.
Strictly speaking, the generational account is defined over all transfers with the government, not just social security transfers.

We will consistently describe the levels of state pensions and of income support as the maximum level of benefits relative to the income of a typical worker, who we take to be a worker with average productivity who supplies 30 per cent of time to paid work. When we talk about the replacement rate of the pension system, we are referring to this ratio.
It is a well-known economic result that the welfare loss from tax distortions rises as the square of the tax rate.
National income is the sum of gross labour income plus interest on the aggregate stock of private sector financial assets; the latter is the sum of wealth held by all agents alive at each point.

The reason for paying attention to the median earner is that they are the voter to whom a party looking to get the most support for their proposals on social security would pay a great deal of attention. (For an extended discussion of this, see Miles and Sefton (2002).)
This section follows Miles and Sefton (2002) closely.
We do not require that the population is constant but, for ease of exposition, we ignore population growth in what follows.

If there were no loss in effective units of time at retirement, individuals would consume less in retirement simply because they have been forced to consume leisure. The empirical evidence is mixed on whether this substitution effect can be observed; see, for example, Blundell, Banks and Tanner (1998). We therefore chose to adjust the utility function to compensate.
